His search has always hitherto been fruitless, and he has sunk back, disheartened, into the sea. But to-night he found Mrs. Pontellier. Perhaps he will never wholly release her from the spell. utterance: Well, I hope you left some suitable excuse.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: No, I left no excuse. I told Joe to say I was outo that was all.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Why, my dear, I should think you'd understand by this time that people don't do such things; we've got to observe les convenances if we ever expect to get on and keep up with the procession. If you felt that you had to leave home this afternoon, you should have left some suitable explana- tion for your absence.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: This soup is really impossible; it's strange that woman hasn't learned yet to make a decent soup. Any free-lunch stand in town serves a better one. Was Mrs. Belthrop here?
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Bring the tray with the cards, Joe. I don't remember who was here.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Give it to Mr. Pontellier.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: The Misses Delasidas.' I worked a big deal in futures for their father this morning; nice girls; it's time they were getting married. 'Mrs. Belthrop.' I tell you what it is, Edna; you can't afford to snub Mrs. Belthrop. Why, Belthrop could buy and sell us ten times over. His busi- ness is worth a good, round sum to me. You'd better write her a note. 'Mrs. James Highcamp.' Hugh! the less you have to do with Mrs. Highcamp, the better. 'Madame Laforce.' Came all the way from Carrolton, too, poor old soul. 'Miss Wiggs,' 'Mrs. Eleanor Boltons.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Mercy! Why are you taking the thing so seriously and making such a fuss over it?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: I'm not making any fuss over it. But it's just such seeming trifles that we've got- to take seriously; such things count.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: It seems to me, we spend money enough in this house to procure at least one meal a day which a man could eat and retain his self-respect.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: You used to think the cook was a treas- ure.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Perhaps she was when she first came; but cooks are only human. They need looking after, like any other class of per- sons that you employ. Suppose I didn't look after the clerks in my office, just let them run things their own way; they'd soon make a nice mess of me and my business.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Where are you going?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: I'm going to get my dinner at the club. Good night.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: A vase fell upon the hearth. Never mind; leave it till morn- ing.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Oh! you might get some of the glass in your feet, ma'am. And here's your ring, ma'am, under the chair.
speaker: the maid

utterance: I hardly think we need new fixtures, Leonce. Don't let us get anything new; you are too extravagant. I don't believe you ever think of saving or putting by.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: The way to become rich is to make money, my dear Edna, not to save it.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Cité can do it as well as I; it is really her business.
speaker: Adele Ratignolle

utterance: Perhaps I shall be able to paint your picture some day.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: I believe I ought to work again. I feel as if I wanted to be doing something. What do you think of them? Do you think it worth while to take it up again and study some more? I might study for a while with Laidpore.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Your talent is immense, dear!
speaker: Adele Ratignolle

utterance: Nonsense!
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Immense, I tell you, surely, this Bavarian peasant is worthy of framing; and this basket of apples! never have I seen anything more lifelike. One might almost be tempted to reach out a hand and take one.
speaker: Adele Ratignolle

utterance: It seems to me the utmost folly for a woman at the head of a household, and the mother of children, to spend in an atelier days which would be better employed con- triving for the comfort of her family.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: I feel like painting. Perhaps I shan't always feel like it.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Then in God's name paint! but don't let the family go to the devil. There's Madame Ratignolle; because she keeps up her music, she doesn't let everything else go to chaos. And she's more of a musician than you are a painter.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: She isn't a musician, and I'm not a painter. It isn't on account of painting that I let things go.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: On account of what, then?
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Oh! I don't know. Let me alone; you bother me.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: So you remembered me at last,
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance:
I had said to myself,
'Ah, bah! she will never come.

utterance: Did you want me to come?

utterance: I had not thought much about it,

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: I sometimes thought: 'She will never come. She promised as those women in society always do, without meaning it. She will not come. For I really don't believe you like me, Mrs. Pontellier.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: I don't know whether I like you or not,

utterance: I have had a letter from your friend,
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Wrote to you?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Yes, to me. Why not? Don't stir all the warmth out of your coffee; drink it. Though the letter might as well have been sent to you; it was nothing but Mrs. Pontellier from beginning to end.

utterance: Let me see it,
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: No; a letter concerns no one but the person who writes it and the one to whom it is written.

speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: It was written about you, not to you. 'Have you seen Mrs. Pontellier? How is she looking?' he asks. 'As Mrs, Pontellier says,' or 'as Mrs. Pontellier once said.' 'If Mrs. Pontellier should call upon you, play for her that Impromptu of Chopin's, my favorite. I heard it here a day or two ago, but not as you play it. I should like to know how it affects her,' and so on, as if he supposed we were constantly in each other's society.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Let me see the letter.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Oh, no.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Have you answered it?

speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Ah! an artist! You have pretensions, Madame.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Why pretensions? Do you think I could not become an artist?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: I do not know you well enough to say. I do not know your talent or your temperament. To be an artist includes much; one must possess many gifts—absolute gifts- which have not been acquired by one's own effort. And, moreover, to succeed, the artist must possess the courageous soul.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: What do you mean by the courageous soul?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Courageous, ma foi! The brave soul. The soul that dares and defies.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Show me the letter and play for me the Impromptu. You see that I have persistence. Does that quality count for anything in art?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: It counts with a foolish old woman whom you have captivated,
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: May I come again, Mademoiselle?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Come whenever you feel like it. Be careful; the stairs and landings are dark; don't stumble.
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Ah, Pontellier! Not sick, I hope. Come and have a seat. What news do you bring this morning?
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Oh! I'm never sick, Doctor. You know that I come of tough fiber—of that old Creole race of Pontelliers that dry up and finally blow away. I came to consult—no, not precisely to consult—to talk to you about Edna. I don't know what ails her.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Madame Pontellier not well?
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Why, I saw her—I think it was a week ago—walking along Canal Street, the picture of health, it seemed to me.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Yes, yes; she seems quite well,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: but she doesn't act well. She's odd, she's not like herself. I can't make her out, and I thought perhaps you'd help me.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: How does she act?
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Well, it isn't easy to explain,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: She lets the housekeeping go to the dickens.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Well, well; women are not all alike, my dear Pontellier. We've got to consider-
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: I know that; I told you I couldn't explain. Her whole attitude toward me and everybody and everything — has changed. You know I have a quick temper, but I don't want to quarrel or be rude to a woman, especially my wife; yet I'm driven to it, and feel like ten thousand devils after I've made a fool of myself. She's making it devilishly uncomfortable for me,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: She's got some sort of notion in her head concerning the eternal rights of women; and—you understand—we meet in the morning at the breakfast table.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: What have you been doing to her, Pontellier?
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Doing! Parbleu!
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Has she,
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: has she been associating of late with a circle of pseudo-intellectual women—super- spiritual superior beings? My wife has been telling me about them.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: That's the trouble,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: she hasn't been associating with any one. She has abandoned her Tuesdays at home, has thrown over all her acquaintances, and goes tramping about by herself, moping in the street-cars, getting in after dark. I tell you she's peculiar. I don't like it; I feel a little worried over it.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Nothing hereditary?
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Nothing peculiar about her family antecedents, is there?
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Oh, no, indeed! She comes of sound old Presbyterian Kentucky stock. The old gentleman, her father, I have heard, used to atone for his week-day sins with his Sunday devotions. I know for a fact, that his race horses literally ran away with the prettiest bit of Kentucky farming land I ever laid eyes upon. Margaret—you know Margaret she has all the Presbyterianism undiluted. And the youngest is something of a vixen.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Send your wife up to the wedding,
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Let her stay among her own people for a while; it will do her good.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: That's what I want her to do. By the way, she gets married in a couple of weeks from now.
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: She won't go to the marriage. She says a wedding is one of the most lamentable spectacles on earth. Nice thing for a woman to say to her husband!
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Pontellier,
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: let your wife alone for a while. Don't bother her, and don't let her bother you. Woman, my dear friend, is a very peculiar and delicate organism— a sensitive and highly organized woman, such as I know Mrs. Pontellier to be, is especially peculiar. It would require an inspired psychologist to deal successfully with them. And when ordinary fellows like you and me attempt to cope with their idiosyncrasies the result is bungling. Most women are moody and whimsical. This is some passing whim of your wife, due to some cause or causes which you and I needn't try to fathom. But it will pass happily over, especially if you let her alone. Send her around to see me.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Oh! I couldn't do that; there'd be no reason for it,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Then I'll go around and see her,
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: I'll drop in to dinner some evening en bon ami.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Do! by all means,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: What evening will you come? Say Thursday. Will you come Thursday?
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: Very well; Thursday. My wife may possibly have some engagement for me Thursday. In case she has, I shall let you know. Otherwise, you may expect me.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: I am going to New York on business very soon. I have a big scheme on hand, and want to be on the field proper to pull the ropes and handle the ribbons. We'll let you in on the inside if you say so, Doctor,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: No, I thank you, my dear sir,
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: I leave such ventures to you younger men with the fever of life still in your blood.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: What I wanted to say,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: I may have to be absent a good while. Would you advise me to take Edna along?
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: By all means, if she wishes to go. If not, leave her here. Don't contradict her. The mood will pass, I assure you. It may take a month, two, three months—possibly longer, but it will pass; have patience.
speaker: Doctor Mandelet

utterance: Well, good-by, à jeudi,
speaker: Leonce Pontellier

utterance: It's a pity Mr. Pontellier doesn't stay home more in the evenings. I think you would be more—well, if you don't mind my saying it—more united, if he did.

utterance: Oh! dear no!
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: What should I do if he stayed home? We wouldn't have anything to say to each other.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: You are too lenient, too lenient by far, Léonce. Authority, coercion are what is needed.. Put your foot down good and hard; the only way to manage a wife. Take my word for it.

utterance: What a pity that so much talent has been neglected! but I must go.

utterance: No

utterance: No!

speaker: Alcée Arobin

utterance: No, no.

utterance: Oh, please don't refuse me! I know something of such things. I might help you with a stray suggestion or two.

Don't think anything of it, don't bother, please. You see, I go when you command me. If you wish me to stay away, I shall do so. If you let me come back, I—oh! you will let me come back?
speaker: Alcée Arobin

utterance: Ah! here comes the sunlight! Now it will be warm and bright enough; I can let the fire alone.

utterance: You are cold; you look miserable. The chocolate will soon be hot. But would you rather have a taste of brandy? I have scarcely touched the bottle which you brought me for my cold.

utterance: Mademoiselle, I am going to move away from my house on Esplanade Street.

utterance: Ah!
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Aren't you astonished?
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: Passably. Where are you going? to New York? to Iberville? to your father in Mississippi? where?
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Just two steps away, in a little four-room house around the corner. It looks so cozy, so inviting and restful, whenever I pass by; and it's for rent. I'm tired looking after that big house. It never seemed like mine, anyway—like home. It's too much trouble. I have to keep too many servants. I am tired bothering with them.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: That is not your true reason, ma belle. There is no use in telling me lies. I don't know your reason, but you have not told me the truth.

speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: They are your husband's,
speaker: Mademoiselle Reisz

utterance: Oh! I see there is no deceiving you. Then let me tell you: It is a caprice. I have a little money of my own from my mother's estate, which my father sends me by driblets. I won a large sum this winter on the races, and I am beginning to sell my sketches. Laidpore is more and more pleased with my work; he says it grows in force and individuality. I cannot judge of that myself, but I feel that I have gained in ease and confidence. However, as I said, I have sold a good many through Laidpore. I can live in the tiny house for little or nothing, with one servant. Old Celestine, who works occasionally for me, says she will come stay with me and do my work. I know I shall like it, like the feeling of freedom and independence.

utterance: What does your husband say?

utterance: Your reason is not yet clear to me.

utterance: Another! so soon! Tell me, Mademoiselle, does he know that I see his letters?

utterance: Never in the world! He would be angry and would never write to me again if he thought so. Does he write to you?

Why do you show me his letters,

Haven't you begged for them? Can I

Oh! Why did you not tell

Oh!
unkind! malicious! Why did you not tell

That he was coming back? No great

He says 'very soon.' You know as

ter.'

But why? Why is he coming? Oh, if

If I were young and in love with a

Now it is you who are telling lies and

utterance:
You are purposely misunderstanding
me, ma reine. Are you in love with Rob-
ert?

utterance: Yes
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance:
Why? Why

Why? Because his hair is brown and

Because you do, in short. What will you do when

Do? Nothing, except feel glad and
happy to be alive.

utterance:
What is the matter with you? I never found you

Don't you know the weather prophet

Well, that ought to be reason enough. You wouldn't give me

utterance:
One of these days, I'm
going to pull myself together for a while

speaker: Edna Pontellier

Don't. What's the use? Why should

Oh, yes! You will tell me that I am

utterance:
No; I shan't tell you anything of the

She says queer things sometimes in a

Well, for instance, when I left her to-

utterance: Whither would you soar?
speaker: Alcée Arobin

I'm not thinking of any extraordinary

speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance: I've heard she's partially demented,
speaker: Alcée Arobin

utterance: She seems to me wonderfully sane,

utterance:
I'm told she's extremely disagreeable

speaker: Alcée Arobin

Oh! talk of me if you like, but

utterance:
I'm jealous of your thoughts to-night.
They're making you a little kinder than

Do you want
to kill yourself?

speaker: Edna Pontellier

Ellen is afraid to
mount the ladder. Joe is working over at

utterance:
Is there anything more you will let me

That is all. Ellen can

speaker: Alcée Arobin

It will be day after to-morrow. Why

And you ask me why I call it a coup

speaker: Alcée Arobin

utterance:
When do you go to the 'pigeon
house?'—with all due acknowledgment to

Day after to-morrow, after the dinner.
I shall sleep there.
speaker: Edna Pontellier

utterance:
